awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Open Core Data: Transformative Data Infrastructure for Integrating and Accessing Scientific Drilling and Coring Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific drilling and coring is crucial for the advancement of the Earth Sciences. Vast
resources have been invested in drilling and coring operations around the world: on land,
in the oceans, and in the polar regions. The return of these investments must be maximized
by ensuring optimal access and re-usability of the data generated through drilling and coring
projects.

This project, Open Core Data (OCD), is a next-generation approach to data management that will 
open vast stores of existing and future geoscience data to new and innovative scientific use by 
radically improving discoverability, accessibility, citability, preservation, and integration 
of data from past, current, and future drilling and coring projects.

Research objectives of the International Ocean Discovery Program and Continental
Scientific Drilling communities provide impressive examples of the breadth of scientific
themes that drilling and coring helps address, ranging from the nature of the deep biosphere
and oceanic sub-seafloor, to understanding environmental change, species evolution, fault
zone dynamics, magmatism, and tectonics, among many others. The scientific potential enabled
by OCD is therefore large and expected to impact many geoscience domains. OCD will form the
nucleus of a federated data infrastructure that will support entirely new scientific approaches
and lines of inquiry by facilitating integration of continental and marine data for synthesis
studies.

OCD will align with NSF data policies to provide open access to all scientific drilling data.
Both research and the process of transferring data to archives for permanent curation will
be simplified and streamlined through this effort. Open Core Data will structure and integrate
scientific drilling data optimally to enable data-driven science that faces substantial barriers
at present related to data heterogeneity in discovery, access, and formats. Open Core Data
will enable geoscience domains that utilize scientific drilling and coring in their workflows
to come closer to realizing the full potential of their data, and to make their own unique
new contributions that benefit science and society as new research is enabled.

por.por_cntn:
Open Core Data -- An Implementation of Research Object for Structured Data Patterns

Open Core Data's goal is to maximize the utility of data from scientific continental and ocean drilling projects to present and future science and to society. Building on existing capabilities and applying new concepts, technologies, and practices for open and semantic sharing of data that have been gaining traction in the geosciences and beyond, OCD will enable scientific drilling and coring data to become semantically discoverable, persistent, citable, and approachable.

Intellectual Merit
Technologically, Open Core Data [1] extends the use of schema.org encoded as JSON-LD for scientific drilling with a focus on Continental Scientific Ocean Drilling (CSDCO) needs. Overall, the structured data approach leverages web architecture and structured data on the web as a means to enable discovery and to support FAIR data principles around machine-ready metadata.

It is moderately lightweight to implement, and leverages patterns already used by many facilities for their web presence. The approach is also implemented by commercial search engines such as Google's Dataset Search [2], provides a foundation for discovery portals such as DataONE, and is aligned with NSF EarthCube community guidance. The Earth Science Information Partners' Science-on-Schema [3] is developing guidance and validation approaches for this implementation and Open Core Data is represented in those meetings and applies this guidance to the metadata.

The implementation of OCD is based on a set of generic components and connected with other open source projects that implement community best practice approaches such as semantic web and object storage patterns. Deployment leverages Open Container Initiative (OCI) containers (Docker containers) and can be easily deployed by others to address similar data needs. An overview of the approach can be seen in figure 1 Architecture Stack.

As a foundation for this, OCD implements the Research Data Alliance (RDA) Digital Object Cloud (DOC) pattern (figure 2 Digital Object Pattern) [4]. This is done in a package called GROW (Generic Resource Object Web) [5] with search enabled via Mercantile [6]. In addition to providing an object based foundation this allows for hosted research objects to be accessed via researcher programs and tools such as notebooks. (figure 3 Object Access). Additionally this approach automates the development of a domain knowledge graph from hosted objects that is accessible via open web architecture patterns.

The architecture can deployed on a local machine or to any commercial cloud infrastructure and leverage native object and graph services. OCD was developed and tested on the NSF XSEDE environment during the course of the project.

Broader Impacts
Open Core Data aims to maximize the return of investment into scientific drilling and coring projects by ensuring optimal access and re-usability of the data generated through these projects. OCD's pattern and elements of its architecture are being leveraged by the EarthCube Coordinating Office and the UNESCO Ocean InfoHub. Additionally the principles being highlighted by Open Core Data, such as FAIR Data and structured data on the web approaches, are important to the broader science community. Open Core Data continues to collaborate with groups such as Neotoma (paleoecology), MagIC (plaeomagnetism) and others to continue to refine these approaches. These contributions are being made to the Earth Science Information Partners Federation (ESIP) Science on Schema work.


[1] Open Core DataOpen Core Data. (2020). Retrieved 28 October 2020, from https://opencoredata.org/

[2] Google Dataset Search(2020). Retrieved 28 October 2020, from https://datasetsearch.research.google.com

[3] ESIPFed/science-on-schema.org"Esipfed/Science-On-Schema.Org". Github, 2020, https://github.com/ESIPFed/science-on-schema.org//. Accessed 28 Oct 2020.

[4] Global Digital Object CloudGlobal Digital Object Cloud. (2016). Retrieved 28 October 2020, from https://www.rd-alliance.org/group/data-fabric-ig/wiki/global-digital-object-cloud

[5] fils/goobjectwebfils/goobjectweb. (2020). Retrieved 28 October 2020, from https://github.com/fils/goobjectweb

[6] earthcubearchitecture-project418/mercantileearthcubearchitecture-project418/mercantile. (2020). Retrieved 28 October 2020, from https://github.com/earthcubearchitecture-project418/mercantile
